section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: In retrospect, do you think it would have been better had the trucks parked where they were initially designated to park?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Oh, absolutely.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And why is that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Well, if the staging areas we were allowed to take, Major Hills Park and Confederate Park, I understand now that that was never part of the deal, apparently. Although, I don’t know; that was all I was told.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And why would have that been better?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: We would have been off the main streets. Occupying or parking all over the city was never part of why we came.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So I’ve just been handed a note to suggest that both you and I are speaking a little quickly for the interpreters.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Oh.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So I will try to slow down and I’ll ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I apologize.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: --- ask you also to try to slow down. No, that’s okay. We’re both to blame so it’s okay. So I’m now going to ask you, and we’ve already touched on it a little bit but about what happened with the people who were originally involved in organizing the convoy. We’ve spoken about Mr. Bauder already but I’m going to now ask you about Pat King. And as I understand it, that in or around January 22nd, 24th, in or around that time period, you and Ms. Lich began having discussions about concerns relating to Mr. King. Do you know what I’m talking about?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. Can you please explain to me the nature of those discussions and what the concerns were?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe the first episode was a CBC article, came out of some past prior social media posts that Pat had been a part of, and we met with Pat, discussed our concerns. I believe we smoothed the waters over, and we carried on at that point.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So do you recall what concerns -- what had been reported in that CBC article that caused you concern?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I don’t really -- I never read the article. There was something about something Pat said years ago. According to Pat, the article was edited or what he said was edited. I can’t confirm or deny that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: I’m just going to pull up a document; it’s HRF00001221, and we’ll go to page 2. And while this document comes up, Mr. Barber, this is a document that has been provided by the convoy organizers’ group. It’s a timeline of events that has been provided. So this was provided to us by your counsel. And if we could go to January 24th at the bottom of page 2. And would it be possible to -- yeah, thank you, Mr. Clerk. So you can read the entry that says, “Concerns re Pat King”; do you see them?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So this here says: “Tamara and Chris discussed concerns about Pat king after viewing a tweet with a video making reference to bullets.” Do you see that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Do you -- is this conversation being described here the same conversation we were just talking about?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Does this refresh your memory at all about what the concerns were?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. Can you please explain?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: This -- the article was made to sound like bullets would be flying, apparently. According to Mr. King, when we confronted him on it he stated that the article was taken out of context, edited to make him sound like he was planning violence, where I believe his -- what he was trying to convey in that article was different than what was portrayed by the media.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And the Commission has seen reports that at some point in time, Mr. King made a comment along the lines of, “This is going to end in bullets”; do you know if that’s what was being discussed?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: That was -- according to what I was told, that was a previous post, two years prior, something to do with an Indigenous standoff.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And during this conversation were you also aware that the media was reporting on a video that -- in which Mr. King had made a suggestion that at some point, Justin Trudeau may catch a bullet one day; were you aware of that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I recall something about that, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Do you remember if that was something you knew about during this discussion, or after this discussion did you learn more about what Mr. King had posted?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe it might have been after.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So it says in here in the second sentence: “Chris agreed perhaps Pat should be sent home but there was concern about the trucks Pat brought with him." Do you see that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What was the concern about the trucks?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Possibly division inside the convoy Pat brought a certain following with. I don't remember the extent of anything after that. We discussed sending him home, and obviously he didn't.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Was the concern that if Mr. King was sent home or asked to not participate that his supporters would also stop participating?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: That would have been a good guess, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So if we can continue on, the next sentence talks about a -- it says: "Talked to Pat about the Tweet on the roadside..." Do you see that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Was that the conversation you had already described to us?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. And was -- were you a part of that conversation?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. And then it says, "Following this, a Captains meeting was held in Kenora [and] at the end of the day where everyone expressed concern about Pat King's involvement."
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Slow down there.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Yeah. Yes, thank you. "The decision was made that someone would talk to Pat within the coming days and request that he not attend in Ottawa." Do you see that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. I'm going to ask you a question about this -- these two sentences, but before I do that, can you just explain what a captains meeting is?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: We had road captains involved in -- approximately two road captains per province to organise the trucks. Those were the people that the people from that province could go to with concerns or issues. So we had a number of road captains within the convoy.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And it sounds in here like after your initial conversation with Mr. King that concerns continued to be raised by other members of the organisation; is that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. And do you know if someone ultimately spoke with Mr. King and asked him not to attend in Ottawa?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Possibly. I wasn't involved in that conversation.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: At any point did you hear from Ms. Lich or anyone else about whether that conversation had occurred?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Not to my recollection, I don't.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And Mr. King continued on to Ottawa.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes, he did.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Were you aware of any resolution having been reached between the people who had concerns and Mr. King?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe whatever happened it worked itself out to the point where Pat stayed with the convoy.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Were you personally concerned about what Mr. King had said previously on social media?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I don't believe it was a concern. He explained to me that it was taken out of context, and then edited to make him sound worse than it was. I took him for his word on it.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So you accepted the explanation at the time?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Do you today still believe that -- do you still accept that explanation?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe Pat had all the right reasons and a good heart.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So I'm going to pull up another document. This is COM00000902. And while we're waiting for the document to come up, Mr. Barber, this is a news article. And we can go to page 3 of the document. This is a news article, and it reports on text messages between yourself and Ms. Lich. And as I understand it, and we will get to this later, when you were arrested the police seized your phone and you no longer have access to the messages on your phone. Is that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And I also understand that we expect to hear from Ms. Lich that she also no longer has access to her text messages. You don't need to comment on that, we can ask Ms. Lich about it. But I'm showing you this news article, and as we go through if there's anything in the article that you think is not accurate, and I appreciate you don't have your phone with you anymore, you can let me know; okay? So if we go down, it says, "On Jan. 22, Lich told Barber they need to have 'a very frank discussion' with King, raising concerns about past allegations [with] him. Despite these concerns, Lich also said he was needed by the movement — in [an] apparent contrast to later statements in which the convoy tried to distance itself from King. 'We need him and I don't care about his past but it only takes one,' she said. 'We have to control his rhetoric. Not even threatening to throw snowballs at the parliament (sic).'" Do you see that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. Do you remember if this is something that Ms. Lich text messaged you?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: My phone was very busy. I'm assuming it's here, so it had to be.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: No reason to ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: No. No.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: --- say this was not a message she sent you?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Right.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: When Ms. Lich said that the movement needed Mr. King, do you know what she meant by that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I can't. I'm not sure.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Do you agree that the movement needed Mr. King?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: The best thing about the movement was it was inclusive to everyone regardless of any beliefs, I guess. Everyone had a place, everybody had a spot. It was just managing how.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So I take it from your answers that, I just want to make sure that I'm fair here, is that you, from what you had learned about what Mr. King had maybe said in the past, the content of those statements didn't concern you because of the explanation Mr. King provided. Is that fair?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I guess. Pat and I had a power struggle between each other, that was pretty evident right from day one. It was just -- it was a power struggle back and forth over control. It wasn't anything that couldn't have been managed.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Did you have any concerns, separate and apart from your own views about what Mr. King may or may not have said, did you have any concern about the public image of having Mr. King associated with the Freedom Convoy movement?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I guess there would've been some concerns at times, I guess. The bad media posts and releases on a regular basis definitely caused some concern.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And can you just explain what you mean by, did you say the ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: The media.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And what was concerning you about the media's coverage?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: They attacked him on a regular basis I believe.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Did you think those attacks were fair?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I didn't know. I didn't -- like I said, I didn't know Pat previous to the convoy. I met him on the 13th for the first time, and things were so busy after that it was hard to keep your head around all the different moving parts.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Other than being busy, is there any reason you didn't do more to look into the people who were associated with your convoy?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: My primary goal was to get those trucks to Ottawa safely. So phone conversations and that were hard to have. Everything that we did was logistics. It was myself on the mic, on the CB mic or the FM radio mic, all day long making sure the trucks were safe. I kind of left that up to other people in the organisation.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: You say -- this media report says that you texted to Ms. Lich: "'I know he's had issues. I've got skeletons in the closet to (sic)...'" Do you see that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Do you recall texting that to Ms. Lich?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. What were the skeletons in your closet?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Well, I've been -- like I've said before, I've been an internet troll for many years.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: At this point in time, was there something in -- was there anything in particular that concerned you about what you had done on the internet?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Nothing that was related to the convoy.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What about things that were unrelated to the convoy?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What concerned you?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I used to post nasty, distasteful memes, be it share memes or just posting online in a negative way.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And the Commission's understanding that some members of the media identified certain Facebook posts that you had made and had reported on them or tweeted about them. Is that something you were aware of at the time?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yeah, they'd been circulated for quite sometime.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. And these include Facebook posts that contained racist and anti Muslim comments. Is that a fair characterisation?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. And I expect you may be asked questions about those by some of the parties, and I wanted to give you an opportunity now, if you wanted it, to speak to some of the racist or anti Muslim things you posted.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Well, I can honestly say that if anybody learned anything or grew more during the convoy it was me. I was a different person nine months ago, whatever it was, ten months ago. Coming out here and seeing the amount of love and the people of all different colours, all different race, everything, it was such a diverse crowd of people here. There was -- so there was so many tears, there was so many hugs, there was so much laughter, there was so much -- it was -- it changed a person, it changed me.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: How did you change?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: It just -- it humbled me, I guess. It made me realise that a lot of those stuff that I used to post on the internet before was very distasteful, and there's a better way to do it.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: One of the things that the media reported on during the convoy was that you had a Confederate flag in your shop in Swift Current; do you know what I'm talking about?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you posted at least one or two Tik Toks addressing that issue; do you recall?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I did, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And one of those Tik Toks you said that the Confederate flag was -- you explained that you -- I believe you'd purchased it in the United States; do I have that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And then you described it as a piece of cloth and get over yourself.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Is that a sentiment you continue to have?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe there's two different contexts to look at the Confederate flag. I've got a good friend that lives outside of Atlanta, Georgia. She's an African American lady. I had a in-depth conversation with her many times on this occasion. She's explained it to me quite well. She said the way the -- the two different contexts, how you look at the flag, was the area of the General Lee and the Dukes of Hazard via, like, Kid Rock, Lynyrd Skynyrd music. When we grew up in our hometown, we had -- we called it a rebel flag or a dixie flag. We didn't really call it a Confederate flag. It was on license plates. It was on back windows. It was everywhere. And at that time, it was more accepted apparently. So in my travels in the deep south years ago, I'd come across a flag store. I seen the dixie flag there. I purchased it. I hung it up on the wall in my shop not thinking anything of it. My African American lady friend in Georgia explained to me that if you wore that flag over your shoulders to a Confederate battlefield, I would probably call you a lot of names. But she said, being the way you're displaying it now and the fact that you loved your childhood watching the Dukes of Hazard and seeing that flag on the roof of the General Lee, it's a different context.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Do you still have the flag in your shop?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: What I did with the flags in the shop was I zip tied them. So they were hanging on the wall of the shop. I went up on a ladder and I zip tied them together. They're still there, but they're not displayed in the correct manner, out of respect for ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And when you talk about how you've changed, is that an example of something you're doing different?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: That would be, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: You've spoken about Mr. King a bit. Once you arrived in Ottawa, did you -- and did you continue to work with Mr. Bauder in terms of the protest activity that was going on in Ottawa?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: No, I hardly seen James the time I was here.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And we've spoken a bit about Ms. Belton. Once you arrived in Ottawa, what was Ms. Belton's role in the convoy?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Same as myself. She was more centralized around the hotel area where we had our daily meetings, making sure things were looked after. My job morphed into more of a outside walking the streets, making sure the trucks were well looked after, making sure the concerns were well, working with the law enforcement on a day-to-day basis, making sure that we had emergency lanes open wherever the trucks were parked. We had a couple different hot spots -- not hot spots, but places in the city that we had -- we'd lost -- we couldn't get the emergency lanes open, and they weren't -- looking back now, they weren't the trucks that came with us from the west. The one issue was Rideau and Sussex. We spent many days down trying to get an emergency lane open, with law enforcement, OPP and OPS.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And we're going to have some questions about Rideau Sussex in a moment. We expect that Ms. Belton may indicate that there's been a falling out between you and her. Is that true?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And what's the nature of that falling out?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Just difference of opinions.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What are the different opinions?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I don't even -- just difference of opinion, different direction. I just chose to stay on a path. My criminal charges have left me to be a lot more silent. I can't speak with, like, what I used to be able to speak about the convoy. I'd rather remain silent. So I've - - instead of fighting with anybody there, I've said my peace and went my different ways.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: If we could pull up a video, HRF146? And, again, I'll give you some context while it comes up. So this is one of your Tik Toks -- just a moment. And we're going to watch it in its entirety and then I'll have some questions flowing from it.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Okay. (VIDEO PLAYED)
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Mr. Clerk. You can pull that down. So I have a few questions arising out of that video. One of the things you say early on is that you want a peaceful protest. And the Commission has seen many instances, and we don't have the time to take you to them all, of where you insist on the protest being peaceful and to the extent there's any sort of suggestion of violence you immediately step in and say this needs to be peaceful. Why was that important to you?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: We had the public on our support. That was -- and I'll apologise for the language there, Commissioner. That was another thing that I've worked on in the last number of months. Look at ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: I've heard worse. I've heard worse. Don't worry.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: That's good. You can take the trucker out of the truck but you -- that was, yeah, most important because we had -- the world was watching us. We had -- there was so many people and safety was utmost. And we were told leave by -- the lawyers flew out, I believe it was the end of the month, the first part of February, something like that, and we were told by the lawyers on the daily basis that we were legitimate protest. We were allowed to be there. We were doing the right things. And the last thing I wanted to do was wreck that for the people that we were trying to represent. And there was a ton of support all across -- all over the world really.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And to put that video into a bit of context, you say that this is a message for the convoy that's coming next week, so -- or arriving. And so we understand that that video is taken probably some time in the week of January 23rd; does that sound right?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So that would have been before you had -- the lawyers had gotten involved and ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: --- you're beginning to get direction from them; is that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So at that point in time when you're emphasizing the importance of a peaceful protest, did you have a concern that the people who were participating in the convoy might not be peaceful?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I'll give you a little example of truck drivers. They're like herding cats. They -- you've got every different style of driver, and I've always said, you put 200 truck drivers in a room and somebody's going to get a black eye and a broken nose. But -- and knowing that going into it, I was worried about that because of the differences of opinion with all truck drivers. I can honestly say that that was something that surprised me. There was none of that. The drivers were well -- and in my -- what I seen, they were extremely well behaved. They listened to the rules of the road. I didn't have a single incident with, to my recollection, with that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So they listened to the rules of the road, I assume you mean on the way to Ottawa; is that fair?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Once you got into Ottawa, was your observation that the protest was peaceful?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe it was loud, but it was peaceful.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Did you see any acts of violence?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I did not, no.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And we'll get to the noise in a moment.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: In another Tik Tok video you posted, and I'm -- and this would have been during the protest in Ottawa, you say that the last thing we need is a January 6th style insurrection, and that was one of your biggest concerns. Do you recall saying that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Why was that one of your biggest concerns?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I believe the federal government was backed into a corner, not wanting to speak to us. And I personally believe that that was the only way, I guess, out of it for them, to demonize us to the point where they could say insurrection when that wasn't the case. And so I pushed that message constantly, daily, peace, love, community. Like I said, it changed with me as a person listening to myself daily saying that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: When you were saying that, was -- what sort of activity were you contemplating that might give rise, either correctly or incorrectly, to the impression that this was going to be some form of insurrection?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: The police build-up. We had daily meetings with police, whether it be OPP or OPS, and everything was positive, but it seemed like the police presence built on a daily basis.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Was there anything that other protestors were doing that were concerning you? And I’m not just talking about protestors within your group. I’m talking about of all the people who were in Ottawa.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Not that I seen, no. The trucks that I looked after on a day-to-day basis were all -- were excited. They were excited. We were two years outside of a -- of lockdowns and mandates and people got to live again. And we seen that on a daily basis.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So another thing you mentioned in the video that we showed was that there was rules of the convoy. You talked about clearing the way for emergency vehicles and that law enforcement need to be respected. Was there any other rules of the convoy?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Basically, that was it. Yes, there was a code of -- I don’t remember if we actually did a code of conduct up or not or we just -- mornings we had tailgate safety meetings with the drivers to make sure that everything was well. There was constant communication with everything. I had no concerns with the trucks. The trucks were always well behaved and, like I said, law enforcement was always open and honest. We did -- we worked really well with every law enforcement that I ever spoke to.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: But at the same time, you recognize that it was important to have rules and try as an organizer to at least have -- try to have some sort of order over the people that were in Ottawa. Is that fair?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: As an organizer, did you believe that you had responsibility for the conduct of the protestors in Ottawa?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I took it upon myself to do everything in my power to make sure that the drivers were notified if things weren’t right. I can’t say it was my responsibility. I don’t -- I can’t act on behalf of someone else. But I definitely did what I could to try and make sure things were done properly.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And what motivated you to do that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Just the sheer size of it and the support. We had support, like I said, all over the country, all over the world, and there was so many people watching. It was -- it was exciting to see the general public -- and one of the biggest things for me it was exciting to see the young kids get back involved with trucks, that were excited for the horn honk, the -- standing on the side of the highway. Kids wanted to be truck drivers again, and I haven’t seen that since I was a child.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So from what I’m hearing, and I want you to correct me if I’m wrong, is that you liked what you were seeing, you felt it was positive and you wanted to try to keep that atmosphere because you wanted to continue the positive experience. Is that a fair sort of summary? Perhaps not the most articulate.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: When you were in Ottawa, what was your views on the police’s responsibilities with respect to peaceful protest?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: They always -- they seemed to respect. I dealt with quite a few on a daily basis, and I can’t -- I can’t say I had a harsh conversation or anything with any of them. Maybe -- police were always respectful. I would walk up to random officers standing on the side of the -- of the street and just -- or sitting in a police car patrolling the barricade and say, “Everything okay? Have you seen anything that was a concern?”. And I never once -- once got a reaction bad.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: In the video we showed, you mention that the “public is on our side and when we start acting like assholes, we lost that”.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Absolutely.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Do you recall that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What did it mean to you to be “acting like an asshole”?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Disrespectful. Not -- not playing by the code of conduct or the rules.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Can you give me an example of something that you believed was -- would be disrespectful?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Being disruptive, I guess. Like I said, we tried on a daily basis to make sure everybody was looked after. So the police had free lanes through, through all. Ambulances had free lanes. I know it was pretty tricky. We worked diligently on it. I lost about 20 pounds in the matter of three weeks with the amount of walking I did working with law enforcement. I didn't -- I had a vehicle here, but it was hard to get around with a vehicle, so a lot of times it was walking. And it was frigid. It was 20 to 30 below. I had two t-shirts on, two hoodies on and long underwear and three pairs of socks at times.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: I won’t ask you if you put the weight back on, so -- because I wouldn’t want anyone asking me that question. You say “acting like an asshole” included conduct that was disrespectful or disruptive. Did you see anything that was disrespectful or disruptive when you were in Ottawa?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Personally I didn’t, no.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And when I say that, I appreciate that not everyone in Ottawa was necessarily someone who had come with your group or who might listen to you. Is that fair?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: That’s fair.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So with that in mind, at any point did you see anything in Ottawa that, you know, that might not be the person who came with you but you wished they weren’t doing it?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I never seen -- like I said, I never seen anything that really concerned me. If somebody was there that wasn’t part of the original group that I brought in, I would try really hard to negotiate with them or work with them to open that lane if they were parked in a spot that wasn’t where it should have been. Sometimes it was successful, sometimes it wasn’t. I really struggled a lot with, like I said before, when it comes to all truckers are different. That dynamic really played in certain parts of the city where ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What was your view on how the protest was portrayed in the media?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: It was a negative light from day one. They -- they -- yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What do you think was being missed?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Everything. I had numerous occasions where people came up to me and said they had to come down and see it for themselves because the media wasn’t portraying it properly. And it was a different thing when they got here.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: The Commission has heard and received -- heard evidence and received written evidence from various residents and municipal officials several complaints about the protestors’ conduct. I expect you’ll be familiar with them, but some of the things that the Commission has heard is that there was excessive noise due to air horns. There was harassment and intimidating behaviour, including people yelling racist or homophobic slurs. And that there was just a general disorder and unsafe conditions, including open fires, propane tanks near buildings and cars. Is this -- is this sort of evidence or concerns, are you familiar with that?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I can honestly say I never encountered a single episode of that. Obviously there was fires for people trying to stay warm. There was -- there was propane tanks for heating things no different than -- I have a propane tank on my porch with a -- with a portable barbecue, so as long as it was looked after safely, I guess.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: In your mind, who was responsible for making sure that -- taking with the propane tanks or other -- or other flammables, who was responsible for making sure the protest was safe? Not that anyone was going to do anything intentional with a propane tank, but something bad could happen and -- and people could get hurt. Who was responsible for avoiding that outcome?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: We left things up to the road captains. Like I said, there was usually two road captains per province (sic), but that morphed into usually a couple road captains per block, and we would hold -- not myself personally. I stayed out of most of those meetings, but the people would hold meetings every day to go over certain things and issues and safety concerns.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: I’m going to now ask you about the horn honking. The Commission has heard evidence and I’m sure you’re aware that at different times in the protest there was a lot of horn honking. I assume you’ll agree with me about that.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Did you consider the horn honking to be a form of peaceful protest?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I considered the horn honking to be a form of excitement more than peaceful protest. I’ll be the first to admit the horns annoyed me. I did everything in my power to try and get the horns to stop. I put out multiple videos on a regular basis saying stop, especially after the Court order came in on, I believe -- whatever date that was, the 7th.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So let’s pause there for a moment. The horns bothered you and prior to the Court order, which was an injunction to stop the horn honking, what steps did you take to limit the horns prior to the Court order?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Speaking to the drivers. It was getting everyone orientated, trying to get them situated in a place where they were safe and their needs could be met, I guess, seeing as our entry was –- was so messed up. I'll use the words. It was organized chaos, unorganized chaos. There was trucks everywhere. There was vehicles everywhere. The only thing I could do was put my videos out stating, you know, like, we're not here to disrupt residents of Ottawa. They didn't ask for this. It was -- the federal government is why we came and did what we could.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So I'm going to show you a video and then a post from your Facebook, so we'll start with the video. This is HRF192. And again, this is one of your Tik Toks.

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yeah, sure.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Sorry. And prior to that, we understand that the Freedom Convoy group had made an effort to have the trucks on the Rideau and Sussex intersection moved onto Wellington Street; do I have that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I was successful with one truck. There was -- if there's -- there was a little -- it was a tractor trailer. He was parked near right by the war memorial. I remember the story on the -- he was parked sideways across the compete intersection. And law enforcement had tried to get him to straighten his truck out for quite some time and failed at it miserably. I remember it was easy. I walked over to the truck. I stepped up on the running board and I said, "Hey, Buddy, you're in the way really bad and you're causing us some grief. Could you just back it up against the curb, please, and you'll save us all a lot of trouble?" And he literally put the truck in gear and backed it up against the -- the OPP and the OPS officers were amazed it was that easy.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: So as I -- I just want to make sure I understand this correctly, in your conversations with the OPS and OPP, you were trying to get a lane open for emergency vehicles; is that correct?

speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: I'm going to now ask you some questions about the other protests that occurred outside of Ottawa in January and February 2022. While you were in Ottawa, did you have any communications or interactions with anyone who was participating in protests in Windsor?

text_clean_combined: Coming near to the end of our time, so I just have a few more questions for you. It's our understanding that after the Emergencies Act was invoked you were one of the people who had their bank accounts frozen; is that correct?

speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Well, my bank accounts were frozen I believe on the day I was arrested, on February 17th. My corporate accounts as well as my joint accounts were frozen for the weekend, unfrozen, I believe, the Monday. My Toronto Dominion Bank account was frozen for upwards of three-and-a-months.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And how did that impact you?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And you mentioned already that you were arrested on February 17th ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: I was.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: --- is that correct?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. How has the arrest affected your life?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: They -- I guess they kind of caught us off guard. They were really professional and really good to work with, I can't say a bad thing about anyone. I was walking with my son and three other of the road captains. So if you Google my name on the arrest you'll see a photo of my grinning. My son was there, he was 18 years old at the time, and I looked over at him and seen him -- that look he had as a 6-year-old or a 7-year-old kid where, you know, the tears were welling up. He was scared. And -- so I simply just said, "Hey, Bud, you're good", and grinned like that, and they caught me on camera, of course. And everything's been good since, it's just it's changed quite a bit.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: What's changed?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. JOHN MATHER
speaker: MR. JOHN MATHER

text_clean_combined: Well, the criminal charges now, and I've never had criminal charges. I've never been in trouble with the law before.

speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

So if we get to here starting with this exchange, we’re not at February 15th, which I believe is the Tuesday, at 8:30. And Kim is asking you how it’s gone moving the trucks effectively and, in particular, how many big trucks you were able to move. So if we could keep scrolling, please. Just the large trucks and not the pickups or cars, and then I believe this is your response, if we keep scrolling. Yeah, can you confirm that you provided this information to Mr. Ayotte; that it’s accurate and that -- any elaboration that you see fit?
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: So to my recollection, we moved approximately 100 vehicles out of the downtown core on that February 15th, 40 of which were tractors, semi units. And apparently approximately 23 were moved up onto Wellington in the one block.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. Now, when you say 23, what happened to the rest of the 40?
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: They moved out of town. They would have went to -- out exit -- we called that Exit 88, Armoire or Antrim ---
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Empire?
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: Antrim?
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Yeah, Antrim truck stop, yeah.
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: Antrim -- there’s two different ones and I always get confused with which one it was. It was the one on the East side of town anyway, so...
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. That was my next question was about the trucks leaving downtown. Now, after this, if we keep scrolling you -- we are -- it refers, I note in passing, to you tiring yourself out, so again, your weight loss. Sorry; if you could scroll up Mr. Clerk, apologies. So then Kim writes to you about running into trouble with any trucks, and then if we can scroll down to your response. I think keep scrolling. Yeah, so if you can just confirm that you wrote this to Mr. Ayotte, and then just provide a little more context for the Commissioner.
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: Absolutely. So February 14th, we had a meeting at City Hall with Kim and Drummond, and I believe Steve, if I’m not correct?
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Steve Kanellakos?
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes. We left that meeting excited, ready to go out. We’d had an agreement that we were going to move as many trucks as we could out of the residential area, up on Wellington. Myself and three other road captains who were close with me went out and started speaking with the drivers, trying to figure out who was ready to move -- sorry; who was ready to move first thing Monday morning, who we could count on, and where we could get them to move. So 7 o’clock in the morning, rolled around Monday morning, February 15th, and we struggled with communication between police, City, and ourselves, as to who allowed the move. So we were on at 7:00 a.m. It was roughly, I’m thinking about 12:30, after lunch before the first police car actually moved and we were allowed to move. So my understanding, we had 72 hours to get as many vehicles out of the downtown core as possible. Something broke down, it was out of my control. We got as many trucks as we could that day, and I remember it was cold, and I -- at the end of the day I was -- I was wore out; I was done. It was a lot of walking; it was a tremendous amount of walking. Something happened at the end of the day, there was a breakdown. I believe Chief Sloly resigned. Something happened where the deal was off the table, and we were -- we were done. So I did everything in my power. We had so many more places on Wellington, we were -- we could have put more trucks. We mapped everything out, we had guys who were ready to move. We ran out of time in the day, on the Monday. And then planned to continue moving on the Tuesday. And, like I said, something fell apart; we were done.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. When you say, “Something fell apart”; you have no further evidence on that for the Commissioner?
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: My communication was with Nicole with OPS, and she’d explained to me that we had our chance -- I don’t remember how; my text messages are at the police station. But we had our chance, and we didn’t accomplish what we agreed to do, and the deal was off the table.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: That was different from what my understanding of what the day was. Where things fell apart, I still yet to understand.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. That’s -- those are all my questions, thank you very much Mr. Barber.
speaker: MS. ALYSSA TOMKINS

text_clean_combined: Thank you.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. Next, I believe, is the Ottawa Police Service.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Mr. Commissioner. This is Jessica Barrow for the Ottawa Police Service. Our questions have already been canvassed, so we have nothing further for this witness. Thank you.
speaker: MS. JESSICA BARROW

text_clean_combined: Okay. And the Ontario Provincial Police.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I have no questions. Thank you, Commissioner.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER DIANA

text_clean_combined: Mr. Sloly’s counsel? (SHORT PAUSE)

speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning.
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Good morning.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: I’m Tom Curry for former Chief Sloly. I just have a few questions about some facts, if you could help us. The trucks, first of all. I appreciate you don’t have a good, accurate count of how many vehicles were in the aggregate of the convoy, or even, I suppose, the western convoy; would that be right?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Can you tell the Commissioner, though, whether the trucks that came with you in the part of the convoy that you had initiated; were those independent operators?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yes. A lot of the major companies didn’t want the advertisements from their business names on the doors for company drivers, so I would say 95, 98 percent of the tractor trailer units were independent operators that would be affected by the border mandates.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Right. And that probably relates, doesn’t it, to your inability to have all of them follow a particular, single set of instructions. Independent operator is more likely to be an independent thinker and ---
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yes. Generally, yes.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And were those independent operators who came from the West operating tractors that had sleeping compartments?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: There was a mix; I’m not sure of the numbers. A very small, what we consider -- they’re called day cabs, where it’s just the cab and no sleeper unit, a very small amount. I remember seeing a handful; yes, there was some -- a few there.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And a day cab operator is not -- by definition, that’s a person who’s not operating a vehicle a long -- on a long haul, unless they’ve got accommodation someplace else, which they wouldn’t normally have?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And so that for the drivers and operators who were in tractors with sleeper units, did they remain in their sleeper units during the period of the convoy?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: I’d say there’d be a good -- a mixed bag. What I kind of realized, the community really came together, so there would be -- the trucks would have to run a lot because it so frigid. What one guy would do, would rent a hotel room and then cycle through drivers to get cleaned up and showered and looked after. The majority of the guys slept in their trucks in the night.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And they’d need fuel to keep running for the reasons that you’ve given; keep the unit warm?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yes, for heat.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And so the fuel, did you recognize it as that, at -- I appreciate what you told my friends that you weren’t 100 percent sure how long this thing was going to last when you came?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Fuel wasn’t something we were worried about at the first. We didn’t know -- I didn’t know what to expect when we got here. I honestly, I had no clue. And so it was confusing to try and keep everything straight in a day.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And fuel became a challenge for you as a convoy organizer, and police and the residents in the community because of the safety; is that fair?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: It did, yes.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And was that one of the things that you tried to work with police to minimize that risk?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: I remember having conversations with some of the officers with regards to what we call a slip tank, which is a fixed 500-gallon tank in the back of a pickup truck with a hose and a pump, was a lot safer and a lot less risk of fuel spilling, compared to people walking around with 5-gallon jerry cans. That wasn’t -- that wasn’t the proper way to do things. And I tried to have a conversation multiple times to get more slip tanks in to put fuel in those trucks compared to safety hazards of the jerry cans.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Right. You hadn’t brought slip tanks yourselves?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: No. No we didn’t.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Right. So there was -- in terms of the organization, the fuel and how you were going to provide fuel for trucks running past, say, the first weekend was not a part of the plan that you had; ---
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: It was not ---
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: --- is that fair?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: No, not at all.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Okay. And then a couple of things, you told us that -- told the Commissioner that you succeeded in moving the load -- I think it was a load safe truck that was on an angle at Rideau and Sussex?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Police had been unable to get that operator to cooperate; and even then, when you turned to the rest of the Rideau and Sussex operators, no luck at all?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: I tried multiple times with Rideau and Sussex and -- good guys, really good guys. And they had a point, and they were protesting and -- yeah, we just had a difference. I did what I could, but ---
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: A couple of other things, and finally, if I could, Mr. Barber, told us, and I don't know want to know what the legal advice was, but early on in this effort, is it right that you turned your minds to what protests, what lawful protests looked like and what unlawful protests looked like?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: We were very fortunate that we had legal. We had lawyers fly in, I believe it was the first week, and we had guidance there. We had somebody that we could -- would tell us what our rights were because, you know, being truck drivers we're not all really good at litigating. So we had lawyers. We had people that could give us advice. We had -- there was a ton of advice there and it was very much appreciated.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Weren't able, necessarily, or maybe at all, to convey -- to put that legal advice into action across the whole spectrum of the convoys though?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And final thing, then. I think on the 7th of February, you became aware that police were intending to mobilise additional personnel in the number of 1,800. Am I right that that signalled to you as a convoy operator that there was going to be a police response coming?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yes, it did, yeah. We knew it was inevitable at some point, I guess. We were hoping it wasn't. We were hoping were able to resolve the issues with the government and we could all go home, but that didn't transpire.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: And you knew as to that, the negotiation, that speaking to police, you've heard about the police, you probably saw them, the police.
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: I spoke with a lot of police liaison.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Liaison.
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: They weren't able to -- they were never going to be able to make a -- to negotiate with you for the kinds of things that you wanted to speak to government about?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: No, they were successful in negotiating between the City I believe and us, and then that was a step in the right direction. We were hoping that one step forward would maybe result in another step higher and we could have an audience. But it didn't...
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: With the Federal Government?
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: With some sort of Federal Government, yes.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Thank you for your time.
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Thank you.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER BARBER

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Commissioner.
speaker: MR. TOM CURRY

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Commissioner.
