text_clean_combined: I could pull it up on my phone faster.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: If counsel has any other documents in paper format, I do have those available ---
speaker: THE REGISTRAR

text_clean_combined: The other document then is BRB00000 -- sorry, 00000062. Do you recognize this document?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: Yeah, those were things that had been posted on a Telegraph site. Who posted them I'm unaware. We were very, very concerned over safety of, you know, protesters and stuff like that.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And for the sake of the Commission and others in the room who are perhaps less familiar with Telegraph, I'm starting to figure out Tik Tok, but what is Telegraph?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: It's a platform that steals a lot of space from my phone. That's about the best way to explain. It's pretty much just a messaging, a fast way of messaging through a group of a bunch of people.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And is it a secure messaging platform?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: I have no idea.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. Fair. If you can focus in on the bottom left-hand corner, I believe it's item number three.
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: There's a mention with respect to ---
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: Excuse me, is there any way to enlarge that for those of us with poor eyesight? Thank you.
speaker: UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER

text_clean_combined: I may have another pair.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: There's a reference to tow trucks, which is a common theme in the Commission -- before the Commission. And I'm just -- if we can perhaps shift a bit to the -- oh, I can see it up here perhaps. Were you aware that people in the tow truck industry were being encouraged not to provide tow truck services to the police?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: Not necessarily, but I understand they've been put in a very rock and hard place kind of position. Had I known they showed up to tow tow trucks, I wouldn't use their service. That's me. I am sure a lot of other truck drivers would have felt the same.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So the message reads: "The most strategic and effective way to protest once you arrive in Ottawa is absolutely nothing. Park your truck on the road, turn off the engine, and let it sit there. No tow truck company would dare tow it away, and if they do, get it on video, and make sure everyone knows not to do business with them. Vote with your wallet." Does that capture the sentiment you just expressed?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: We do that with lots of things. We don’t like what Coca-Cola said, we don’t buy Coke any more. We don't like what somebody says about children or animals, we don’t buy their product any more. It's the same thing. Tow truck services are a product. If we don’t like what they do, we don’t have to buy their service.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So for them to assist the citizens of Ottawa and tow the trucks, or to assist the police and tow the trucks, that would result in not buying their services?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: I wouldn't buy their service. They weren’t in support of the Canadians.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Mr. Clerk, do we have the video now?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: If you could just briefly repeat the document ID, I should ---
speaker: MR. JASON THERIAULT

text_clean_combined: Yes. PB.CAN.00001777_REL. And for the record, Commissioner, I would have ended a lot earlier. I know I've burned a bit of my time in previous rounds, so this one, I hope -- here we are. (VIDEO PLAYBACK)
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: As I said, it was more directed to St. Bridget's, but ---
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And you said she threatened you in the TikTok video.
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: She did.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And what was the nature of that threat?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: The threat was that if I used my voice and did any more media that she would include me in the lawsuit with the City of Ottawa.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And if you did not? If you were silent?
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: If I was silent -- there was no, "If you're silent", but that was the threat.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Thank you. I have no further questions.
speaker: MR. ANDREW GIBBS

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Next, the convoy organizers.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: --- CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR. BRENDAN MILLER:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Sir, I am going to ask under -- I can't recall the rule -- but with respect to the order of examination, as we got the documents from this particular witness, several hundred of them, not until this afternoon, I do have concerns from the brief ones I have reviewed, and I have given a written objection to your counsel with respect to those. What I would like to do in the meantime, sir, is I would like your leave and approval to examine this witness following her paralegal examining her. I can tell you, at this point, I don’t have many questions for this witness at all. My concern is the beginning of a character assassination as well as attacking my client, the corporation itself. And given what was just asked by the Government of Canada and what was just said, I would like to sit back and see what the evidence is with respect to the character assassination evidence that I think this witness is intending to give, before I do my examination, sir.
speaker: MR. BRENDAN MILLER

text_clean_combined: Okay. Well, I'm not sure we should be talking about character assassinations; rather, there are some issues (audio skip) raised. I think let's try and not inflame things and take one step at a time. So you'd like to defer at the moment, and maybe I can hear from ---
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I'm okay with that.
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I don’t mind if we go first. I think that’s what he's saying. That’s okay.
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Okay. So that should not be a problem. So let's go through the rest of the roster and then we can get to that. Okay. So next, the Ottawa Residents.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: --- CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR. PAUL CHAMP:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good afternoon, Ms. Belton. My name is Paul Champ. I'm the lawyer for the Ottawa Coalition of Residents and Businesses, and I just have some questions for you, further to your testimony today. You testified earlier, Ms. Belton, that it was not your intention to disrupt the lives of residents of downtown Ottawa; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: But you did recognize that the activities of the protest, the trucks taking up all of the streets and the horns and so forth, did indeed disrupt resident who were living within the six or eight blocks of those activities?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: As did millions of Canadians that demanded people get vaccines and demand that they wear masks and demand that they be thrown to the ground. Yeah, I understood what had happened over the last two years, and I'm sorry they were affected for three weeks, but I suffered for three years -- well, two years.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And did you associate the people with downtown Ottawa with the Government of Canada? Like, did you assume that these were government -- federal government workers in some way who deserved that disruption?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: No, that would be ludicrous.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And on your arrival in the city, we've heard some evidence about a strategy to gridlock the city. Can you tell us about that?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I wasn’t part of that (audio skip).
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: What was the plan, as far as you understood, with the 400-plus semi tractor trailer trucks converging on downtown? Where did you think they would go?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I understood there were two locations we were to go, but that the police had redirected us. Once we got together at the ARC, we started to hear concerns, and I believe the guys were working on it, doing whatever they could to deal with the logistics issues. I did not deal with the logistics issues in Ottawa.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: You were a road captain managing the convoy of trucks from Southwestern Ontario to Ottawa; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, and I went where the police directed us, which was nowhere near your residents, by the way.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Where -- sorry, what does that mean?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That means your residents were further north.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Ours were on the SJAM. There was no residents where we had been. We were in front of the War Memorial.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I believe that’s the War Memorial.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: There is. You would have seen the apartment buildings there in front of your trucks?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: No, it was further back.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: It was not right directly with the truck.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: With respect to mask mandates -- I understand your position with respect to vaccines -- you are also opposed to mask mandates; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I'm not opposed to mask mandates. I'm opposed to women who are victims of violence to be forced to wear them or be thrown to the ground.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Were people in restaurants and stores throwing people to the ground? Is that what you observed?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I observed video from Canadian Tire and Costco both where securities threw people to the ground. Also, a woman in BC that had no hands, arms from the elbow down was refused service at a grocery store because she couldn't put a mask on. So the general public lacked empathy and sympathy for those that could not comply.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Did you have sympathy or empathy for people who were elderly or had medical conditions where they'd be susceptible to dying from COVID-19?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Absolutely, but we have never locked up the healthy, ever.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Now, with respect to the mask mandates, there was a lot of people in the convoy demonstrations who were very opposed to masks and mask wearing, correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Everybody had their own belief. Some wore masks, some didn’t. There were people on the street that wore masks.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Can I object? That question doesn’t go to the mandate that was established for that process so why should she have to answer questions about that.
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: I don’t even believe there was a mask mandate in effect at that time.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Indeed, there was. I’m not sure if I understand the objection, Ms. Scharf.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: The objection is that the protest was not about masks. It was about truckers, mandates for truckers for travel.
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: I think we’ve heard a great deal of evidence, if we follow the train ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, now, there is ---
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I apologize.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I’m sorry.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I apologize.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: There is a process. You speak through me. Ms. Scharf, I understand your point, but this is cross-examination so I tend to give a little latitude. So if that -- I think that question is within that latitude.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: So, Ms. Belton, we’ve heard previous evidence from the police and others about some convoy protesters being very upset about people wearing masks and doing protests by going into stores and shops and restaurants in large groups without wearing masks. Did you observe those kinds of activities while you were here?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I observed maskless people. I didn’t see protests. You might want to talk to those that caused the issue. That was not me.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So when you went into restaurants and shops, you wore a mask during the convoy protest?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Sir, I’m a victim of violence and I won’t put a mask on to make you feel better.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: So when I have to go through what I have to go through and take Ativan because you want me to wear a mask, and then you don’t want me to drive a car however I live in the country, I take issue to that. I can’t walk home. I don’t live in a city centre like you do. So yes, there are issues on both sides and there is no compassion on this side. That is the issue. You are painting this exactly like the Toronto Star did. You have no empathy for us.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So I take that as a no, you didn’t wear masks when you went into stores or restaurants ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: No, because I’m a female victim of violence and you need to respect that.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And did you observe others that you’d go with into stores and shops wearing -- not wearing masks, the people you were with?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That was asked answered. Yes, the answer was yes.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And what would -- how would people respond when shop owners or staff, sometimes young teenage staff would say, “Please where a mask”? What are some things you observed in those interactions?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I didn’t have those interactions.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: No one ever asked, “Can you please where a mask or leave?”
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: No, sir.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: With respect to the money -- so you were aware before you got to Ottawa that there was the large fundraiser, people were raising funds to support the truckers with covering their fuel, and their food, and their -- and so forth; you were aware of that?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, Tamara did an amazing job at raising funds for us.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: For sure. And -- but by the time you arrived in Ottawa, you recognize it was in the multimillions that had been raised; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And when you came to Ottawa, how long did you think you’d be staying?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Twenty-four (24) to 48 hours.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And you required $10M to stay 48 hours?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Canadians thought our voice needed to be heard and we needed to be supported.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So you were planning to leave in 48 hours because you assumed the government was going to agree with your demands?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: We thought we would get a meeting.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. So what changed? Why didn’t you -- why did you stay after 48 hours?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Because Justin Trudeau did exactly what he’s done for the last two years. He literally came out and called us a whole bunch of names. I’m sorry, sir, but if I came and called you a whole bunch of names and said that your ideals and how you felt didn’t mean anything to anyone, how would you feel? And that you losing your job, your income, your way to pay your wife’s expenses to put food on the table for your children was irrelevant, how would you feel? So because of his actions, there are consequences, and that meant we stayed.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So, Ms. Belton, then, if I understand your answer correctly, your plan was to come for 48 hours assuming the Prime Minister would respond to your demands but, if he did not, you were going to stay until he did; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I didn’t say that.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So what are you saying?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I’m saying we were looking for a meeting.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And you were going to stay until you got your meeting?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Some sort of response would be good.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So you were going to stay until you got your meeting?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Or a response.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Now, you stayed in a -- you stayed in the Arc Hotel for most of the time?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Most of the time.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Who paid your hotel bills?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Joseph Bourgault from what I understand.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And the -- there was also money raised in cash. You’ve told us in your testimony that, in the Arc Hotel, you were putting together envelopes to hand out to the truckers because many of them were staying -- living in their trucks; right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That’s where truckers live.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Yeah, they were living rough. That was very tough for them. And so you were putting together envelopes of $2,000 to assist them with their expenses; right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Now, the fuel that they were getting, they were getting jerrycans of fuel and so forth to keep their trucks running to keep warm, I understand; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I understand the same.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Well, you were involved in it, though, right? You were involved in the logistics?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Not everything.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Not everything, but you were involved in meetings where there’s discussions about how to get the fuel to those trucks that were still running?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, I may have been dealing with something else at the time.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Right. And the fuel that they were getting, they were getting that for free because that was being provided by someone else; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I don’t know that.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: You weren’t involved in those meetings?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I don’t know who paid for what.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. Now, the envelopes that you were handing out, how often did you do that; how many rounds were there of envelopes being handed out?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I know of two instances.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: From the Arc Hotel?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And then the Sheraton Hotel, they were also handing out envelopes, is your understanding?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: You’ll have to ask them.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Well, you testified, I believe, that you understood that the Sheraton was handing out ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, that’s the end of my understanding.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Fair enough. Well, just for your assistance, Mr. Barber testified about that and, indeed, they were handing out ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: And he was over at the Sheraton.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Right. And how would you know or how did you keep track if truckers were getting the same -- were getting envelopes from multiple groups.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: We would ask them.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Just a reminder, you’re out of time so if you could try and ---
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Don’t I have 15 minutes, sir.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I had a note “10 minutes”, so.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Well, if I may, Commissioner, ask for leave for five extra minutes. I think I was getting some longer responses than anticipated.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I’ll give you a few more minutes but please keep it to the point.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Commissioner. I believe I’m trying to be on point for my clients. Thank you. So with respect to honking, Ms. Belton, as a truck driver, you’re aware airhorns and train horns can be extremely loud?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, they have a purpose; they’re warning signals.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Yeah, they’re -- trucks are heavy; they can be dangerous vehicles; they need very trained people to drive them; and if there’s a hazard or something far away, you use those very loud horns to ensure people absolutely know that the truck is coming or there might be a risk.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: So we’re noticed, yes.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Yeah. But the sound of the horn, it can be dangerously if you continue to hold on it; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: So could be a racetrack, an airport, several other things.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Absolutely, I agree with you. Now -- but the horns were used by the trucks as a sort of -- a symbol of the protest throughout their time in Ottawa; is that fair?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, I noticed on your lawsuit, you didn’t list every child that came and honked a horn. They are also responsible, are they not?
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So I take that as a yes, that you’re aware that horns were used as a protest tactic?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: They were -- no, they were used by the drivers. Some were having fun. I do know that Chris and the rest of them had talked; we needed to get the horns down to a minimum. We also needed to do some sleep time because some were in the city making louder noises. We did try to assist citizens.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: M’hm.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: It’s not that we left you out to dry. We tried to assist citizens.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Now, Ms. Belton, there was a schedule of horns, was there not? There was a time -- they would start at 7:00 a.m. and go on throughout the day; isn’t that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Not that I’m aware of.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Not that you’re aware of? You were downtown; you didn’t hear those horns?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I don’t know of a schedule for the horns.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. You say that you tried to control the horns; is that right? Is that what you’re telling us?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I said organizers tried to control the horns. I never went out except for once during some speeches on the Hill where there was a vehicle that was making excessive noise. Actually, I think there were maybe two of them. I went up to both and I said, “Look, guys, that’s enough.” One complied, one didn’t.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Some of the other organizers, though, very much supported the horns at any time; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I wouldn’t know. You’d have to ask the other organizers.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Well, in your discussions, like, for example, with Pat King, Pat King was very much in support of the horn, was he not?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: In emergency use.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: In emergency use only?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: From what I understood, his direction was, if you’re in trouble, to honk your horn.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. Just a final point, Ms. Belton, you’ve testified that the mayor’s deal that we’ve heard about, your understanding at the time was that that was fake news; it wasn’t true; there was no deal; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And the people that you knew and that you were dealing with at the Arc Hotel opposed any deal in any event; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: No, I never said that.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So what are -- so you would have supported a deal? If there had in fact been a deal to move the trucks to different locations, you would have supported that kind of a deal?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Absolutely. If we could have lessened the events to the citizens, absolutely. We weren't there to disrupt the citizens, we were there to have our government finally hear us after two years. I did my due diligence, sir. I wrote 32 letters. I went the right way, and no one listened to me. So I don't know what you expect of me, but bringing my truck, well, I brought my pickup truck, I didn't bring a big truck. Did they notice me? Did somebody finally try and come and talk to me? The answer to that is still no. So what do I need to do have my government, that is elected, to talk to me? To help me solve my problems. You had horn honking. I watched people get thrown to the ground. I watched children in parks getting thrown off their skateboards by police officers. No one helped those people. Matter of fact, people were supporting this kind of behaviour. This is not the behaviour of a free country.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So in your view, the people of Downtown Ottawa were unfortunate casualties. If the Prime Minister had listened to you, what happened to the, those three weeks of sleeplessness and so forth, that wouldn't have happened? It's the Prime Minister's fault?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I feel for them, I honestly do, but I feel for those truck drivers that were about to not be able to feed their families. Many of those drivers had their whole families in those vehicles. With no income they lose their home. Kids are raised in a truck until school age. We had a one-month old baby that the City of Ottawa took fuel from and we had to find accommodations so it didn't freeze to death. Which is more inconvenient? Not having fuel and watch your child freeze to death or listening to a few horns? I am sorry that your clients feel that they are entitled to $460 million for horn honking. Who was going to replace my income if I took a vaccine that killed me so my husband could survive? Not any one of your clients I guarantee you.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: But you inflicted that on my clients ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: And your clients ---
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: --- so that you could get your message back to ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: --- supported vaccine mandates.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: You're well over your time, and I think it's turning into a debate, which I don't think is constructive.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Mr. Commissioner.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Okay, next, call on the Ottawa Police Service.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I have no questions, sir. Thank you.
speaker: MS. JESSICA BARROW

text_clean_combined: Okay. The Ontario Provincial Police. You're still on mute.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I have no questions. Thank you, Commissioner.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER DIANA

text_clean_combined: You're still on mute.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Can you hear me now?
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER DIANA

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Sorry about this. I have no questions for the OPP.
speaker: MR. CHRISTOPHER DIANA

text_clean_combined: Okay, thank you. Counsel for former Chief Sloly?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Okay. And I take it that's because they stayed despite police attempts to remove them from the border?
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: Right. They maintained their blockade despite attempts to remove them?
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: I'm assuming so, I wasn't there.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: Not likely.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And if they told you that there were too many horns and asked for your help to stop the horns, I take it your view would've been it's up to the individual protesters to determine how they protest?
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: I assisted when asked.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: When asked, and I suggest to you when you agreed with what you were being asked.
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: You can suggest that but you weren't there.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. So you disagree with me, you would have gone along with what ---
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: I went along with a lot of the things that made sense.

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: If it didn't make sense -- I make horn honking, I can understand why people want that reduce, absolutely. However, when the government goes and says you can't honk your horn but we want you to leave, they obviously didn't read the Schedule 1 of a truck, which means you have to honk your horn in order to leave the city. So what, did you want to us to leave or did you want us to stay? We couldn't complete a Schedule 1.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And just a couple more things. We've heard some testimony about the swarming of police officers. Did you witness that?

text_clean_combined: I did not witness that.

text_clean_combined: Okay. And do you have any information, I take it you didn't witness it, but do you have any information about which groups were involved in that?
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: I do not.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: You also testified that Pat King was the lead on media in January; correct?
speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: That's what he agreed to. He agreed to put out media for us, to put us through to his followers that would allow us a broader reach. Just kind of like, I don't know, when you do a newspaper ad, except it was free, so thank you Pat.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And did Mr. King, to your knowledge, did he continue to take a lead role in the information that was being disseminated into February?

text_clean_combined: Sure. And my question was only did that sort of lead role continue into February?

text_clean_combined: I know some of the organisers asked him not to do so much. speaker: MS. REBECCA JONES

text_clean_combined: --- over time? And was that on the basis that Facebook said you were spreading disinformation?

text_clean_combined: You're welcome.

text_clean_combined: You called the number afterwards?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: Not directly. A few months later.

text_clean_combined: A few -- oh, so they left you a telephone number to call back at?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: No, I screenshotted the message when they called. I screenshotted their phone number.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And you called them back later, and then how did they identify themselves when you called back later?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: I'd have to recall the number. Would you like me to try?
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: No. I can't ask you to try that now. I'm just asking you, how do you know that when you called back, like, a few months later, they were a police officer?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: Because they had no connection with the Royal Bank.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: When you spoke to them a few months later?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: I did not speak to them. I called them back and got a message machine. It stated their name and no association with the Royal Bank.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So it was (audio skip) corporate voicemail where the person would answer, "I'm so-and- so of the Royal Bank of Canada at this branch"?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: You're correct.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you said that your bank accounts were frozen for a period of time, but you said you don’t recall for how long because your husband manages the banking; is that fair?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: That’s fair, yeah. He dealt more with that. I was dealing with, of course, other situations, other people not having money, trying to help truckers get home. The freezing of the bank accounts created a larger problem than solving the problem.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And in terms of the length of the problem, do you know -- can you provide your best estimate of whether your bank accounts were frozen for a period of days or whether it was a period of weeks after February 17th?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: I can't be -- I can't nail down a time for that. I know it was a very long time that I did not have access to funds, or it felt that way.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And do you know that because by March 1st you had a mortgage payment due that you weren’t able to make?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: That’s right. A friend went and made that mortgage payment for us. They went and deposited the money for us, so that would be correct.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And so can you just elaborate for me how on a person basis the freezing of the bank accounts affected you with respect to your personal bank accounts, other than the payment of your mortgage?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: Other than the $100 that was gifted to me by another participant, I couldn't put fuel in my pickup truck. I live nine hours from Ottawa, so I couldn't get home. I couldn't pay for my husband's diabetic medication. We were looking for solutions to that, because the money we had, we had to decide what that was going to pay for, his -- the one unfrozen bank account, which wasn’t a main bank account. That’s not where we put all our expense money. So my expenses are now -- he's trying to cover. He's trying to cover his expenses. He's trying to cover his business expenses. He's trying to cover everything out of a very small account that’s just meant for him to do with -- you know, buy groceries or food in the U.S. Our lifestyle is a little different and it's very hard for people to understand that do not truck. There is usually a joint account to pay things that either husband or wife can do, because we never know when we'll be home. My estimate time away is approximately 289 days a year, equivalent to 4.5 trips around the earth in a year. So we need to work together to make sure our bills are paid.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So if I can summarize, your access to the joint bank account that you have with your husband is essential to manage your household finances because of the time that you spend away from home?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And the only bank account that you had access to was the personal bank account of your husband's that was not frozen?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: I did not have access to that. That is his personal bank account. So he had access to money on the road. I was in Ottawa nine hours from my home and I had access to nothing.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Can you -- I asked you about your experience personally with respect to the freezing of your personal bank account.
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: You're well over your time, so you're going to have to wrap up, please.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Okay. Yeah, so this is my -- going to be my last question, and I apologize, Commissioner. Can you just elaborate on how it affected your business to have your business account frozen?
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: How it affected our business?
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MS. EWA KRAJEWSKA

text_clean_combined: We ended up having people - - we actually, I believe, just deferred the payment a month. We had to call and defer the payment.

speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Perfect. And what was the approximate date of that video?
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: November 17th? It's either the 16th or the 17th.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: That’s 2021 or 2020?
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: Twenty twenty-one (2021).
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Twenty twenty-one (2021). And you had indicated in your testimony that you were afraid that, you know, Windsor police would be involved, other policing agencies. speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: On that day, when I crossed in, I tried to explain to the Windsor border CBSA agent that I could not wear a mask, that my visor that I usually used had been broken during the trip. We finally got to the, "She's not got one", and I tried to explain. It was not good enough. He was on some sort of power trip, and he told me to enjoy my time with the Windsor police. text_clean_combined: But when you entered, did you actually have an interaction with Windsor police on that particular day?
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: No. My interaction first was with a CBSA officer that was yelling at me to get back into my truck. I had waited a long time for them to come see me, so I was like, have we gone back to the old rules where you got to go in? So I went to go in and I was yelled to get back in my truck. I got back in my truck. I did as I was told. And then I had the officer ask me if PHAC had called me. I believe at that point, they hadn’t. The second time, they had. PHAC said they were waiting on police to arrive to issue a $6,000 fine or of that nature.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And just to say, PHAC, here you're talking about the Public Health Agencies?
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: That’s what they called them, yeah.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Perfect. You also indicated in your earlier testimony that you had witnessed a CBSA strike a number of years ago and that you had been left to sit on the bridge for over two hours.
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: Yes, sir.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Do you recall about when that occurred?
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: I actually have it within my files. I believe it was 2020, possibly August. It's in my files. I don't have it right in front of me.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And that was the Ambassador Bridge as well then?
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: I was on the Bluewater at that point. The CBSA strike was more than one bridge. It was unilateral. It was all over the news.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And when you were on the Bluewater Bridge that day and your truck was at a complete standstill on the bridge as in no traffic was entering Canada through that port of entry because of the actual CBSA officers; is that correct?
speaker: MR. ANTOINE D’AILLY

text_clean_combined: It was entering almost in reverse mode. It was extremely slow. I sat on the bridge. I looked down and from my location you can see their parking lot. And in front of their parking lot, they had their picket signs. text_clean_combined: Okay. First off, the original map, I believe the Commission number is BRB00000217. (VIDEO PLAYBACK)

text_clean_combined: If it's helpful to counsel, would -- is there a place where you'd like to start or just start?
speaker: THE REGISTRAR

text_clean_combined: There is a dialogue on it. (VIDEO PLAYBACK)
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Can you start it at the beginning? We missed some of it. It was sort of muted. Okay. Thank you. (VIDEO PLAYBACK) This is the secondary map that we had in Ottawa. The first one is not available to me. This was the other one that the printing came out a little blurry, so we didn't use it as much. We did put some notations on it, but this is the map that we had in our boardroom. And this is the Transportation Master Map plan 7 -- or map 7 from the City of Ottawa website. It was blown up. That was supplied to us by Andrew Peloso. So on January 28th, the southwestern Ontario GTA and Niagara Region arrived in Ottawa. We were led down the Ottawa River Parkway by the police. They told us to take this route even though it was a non-truck route. And the Carling exit onto the Ottawa Parkway was very difficult for trucks to make, bobtail and with trailers. The police had it barricaded and removed the barricades in front of me to allow us to go onto this JAM. We arrived here and were brought over by the war museum. The police had a blockade right here and would not allow trucks to go up onto Wellington. On January 29th, when the western group came in, led by myself, Mike as the second pilot car and Chris Barber as the lead truck, came up onto the Ottawa Parkway. Police then moved their barricades, which were barrels, they were barrel barricades, and allowed Chris to bring his truck up onto Wellington, approximately this area right here, just before the Parliament Hills. He was pretty much across from the parking area, because I remember parking close to there. They did not let the rest of the trucks come. They all remained behind the barricades that were put there in place by the City of Ottawa Police. Trucks were on both sides. A lane was open on both sides. They used the centre medium [sic] for their kitchen, and along the sides of each roadway each direction is where the cars and trucks parked. The full intention with this map was to make sure that we left lanes open and emergency routes available for quick access for police. We knew that there were several hospitals or care homes in the area. It was very important to us to leave those open. There was Élisabeth Bruyère Centre right up here. And we wanted this route straight here, straight down open as well as through to Rideau and down to the 417 open. It was imperative. It was very important for us to leave access for emergency vehicles. I had a friend who was a resident at Élisabeth Bruyère, so that was very important to me. And being a long-term resident of the Ottawa area and a former City employee, safety is definitely top priority for myself and we worked as a team to make that happen. So we were aware that there was a lot of vehicles in the area. We were trying to solve the parking problem and get more trucks off the streets, making almost two lanes open. In some places we succeeded around he Bank Street area. Lower Bank Street area we were able to do that. So we were looking for other parking. The problem was getting them in and out of areas. So we knew there was parking down here. We knew there was parking over here. But to get big trucks in and out was an issue and to make sure that the police didn’t block off the access, so trucks could come and go at their will, should they decide that they wanted to leave. We also had notes on this map. You’ll see over here at the side. These notes are of leaders. And they’re designed roles. The first one we have would be Pat. It states right here that we knew right from the beginning -- because this map was done within the first two days of being in Ottawa, so approximately between the 29th and the 2nd of February, I would say. Approximately the first two days we started working on this. To the best of my knowledge this map was done within the first few days of us being in Ottawa. We were working on a smaller printed map but Andrew, of course, provided these for us which was a great help. As you can see, Pat was on here. This is not my writing. To the best of my knowledge this is Tom Marazzo’s writing but he would have to confirm that. Pat was here for video information and output of social media. That was his primary goal. However, Pat was very very instrumental in helping us solve problems with great suggestions for the truck drivers. As you see, Tamara had -- Tamara Lich -- and that was Pat King, sorry. This is Tamara Lich. She has no dedicated spot to her name. However, when we were on a Zoom call, approximately between January 12th and January 14th, her role was designated as social media and fundraising, crowd funding. Chris -- this is Chris Barber. He and I are talking to the troops. He did a very very good job at talking to a lot of the truckers and getting his picture taken and being there for the issues. These marks represent the amount of people I was giving credit to for bringing trucks here and I have forgotten a lot now that I look at this map. There are far more than eight and then we had four more, of course. Those were the key eight were the four starters. So that would be myself, Chris Barber, Pat King, and James Bauder. Then we had eight more underneath. Those would be ones that we had brought into the organization through social media calls, however we touched base. The B.C. organizer is listed here as Sean. This is not the same writing. I’m not sure who wrote this on the map because the B.C. coordinator that I was dealing with was Colin and his last name escapes me at the moment. We also had it as all of the west as Chris somebody wrote that in there. West was -- there was a lady by the name of Kathy. There was Chris. There was James Bauder. I don’t know Kathy’s other name, her last name. Southwest they have Ben -- that would be myself. Ben, I don’t have his last name. He’s ADD Trucking. We have myself and Tim and Herald Yonker. The GTA was David Steinberg. We also had in Ontario -- we have Mike Benson and Andrew Dichter. Those were also associated with myself. Quebec was Joanie. I'm not sure of her last name. I know it starts with a P. The PC coordinator was Joanay (phonetic). Her last name, to the best of my knowledge is Paquette. I haven't checked my emails to give you that information 100 percent. I apologize. And New Brunswick, PEI -- Leanne, Indi and Ben. I have no idea what these two indications are on the map at this point. (VIDEO ENDS)

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: I'm sorry I didn't make it clear.

text_clean_combined: I don't know what it's been numbered, and I'm not sure ---

text_clean_combined: Okay. Maybe you can just testify to that if you remember now which one that was.

I didn't think it was a big deal, but we were told we were not allowed to talk about it.

speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: I think we'll leave that. She had some other ones, but... There was just one more item. Actually, two more items, but one, the CB -- now, I'm frustrated too. CBSA, the letter that you wrote to the CBSA, and their response.
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Right. We don't have it. Okay, the CBSA letter came in December, and it basically made no accommodations for those that couldn't wear a mask, those that - - they just wouldn't make accommodations. And I had had a PHAC there at one point in February of 2021, and they woman's name was Jessica, and she had given me exemptions. My company that I was working for at the time even wrote a letter based on her name on the face mask requirements from PHAC that they give you. She wrote her name, said that if there was any problems just to refer to her. That never happened. So every time I went through there was an issue. It depended on what agent I got, whether the issue was a small issue or a massive blown out fight between CBSA and myself.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you wrote a letter of complaint?
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: My husband actually took the initiative because I was done. I didn't plan on staying. I didn't plan on breathing. Couldn't do it.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And ---
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: I planned to end my life and give him everything, but for some reason I was here to cause a ruckus I guess. And I couldn't do it as fast as I would like to do. My husband went ahead and filed the complaint first on my behalf. CBSA wouldn't allow it. I told them that I was afraid of repercussion at the border, that this would continue to strain the relationship between myself and CBSA. And after their letter of basically not providing accommodation, following the rules of Ontario, which were -- you didn't have to be masked if you actually had a valid medical reason, I think going back to a terrible time in your life is a valid medical reason, and they minimised the suffering and the experience with them at CBSA. And I wrote them back and I said, "Please don't underestimate what you've done." I had at that point started on a downward spiral of rapid weight loss. My southbound trips were fine, but my northbound trips were unable to sleep, tossing and turning, not eating, losing rapid weight, shaking driving up to CBSA. At first, it was just a little bit, then it became more and more strenuous, more stressful, and it just started compiling. Shaking driving from Texas to Ontario and actually being so overwrought on the second day that I had to take a day, and I couldn't move, I couldn't get out of bed. I had to take a day to kind of get my stuff together and continue on. So it was a very traumatic experience, although CBSA thinks they were just doing their job.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: So after you got the response back from CBSA, you wrote to various MPs and other officials. Do -- can you state the names of those individuals and roughly what you were asking them for or what to do?
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: I was asking for help. Help. I wanted help. I wanted someone to help me. Some of those messages I believe start with "9-1-1. "Help. I need help." Randy Hillier, Roman Baber, Lianne Rood, maybe even Monte McNaughton, I know there were letters to him. I went federal, I went provincial. Nobody listened. Nobody helped.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: What was your ---
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: I don't want to listen to your staff member when I'm having an issue that is life- changing, I want to talk to you. I want to sit down with you, whether it's with a Tim Horton's coffee or a bottle of water, and let's figure out the problem and find some solutions. But those weren't available.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: And ---
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: How many of those emails did you send?
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Approximately 32.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. So I just have one last statement. You indicated to me that your grandfather had given you an explanation of the conditions under totalitarianism or communism. You recounted that to me. Can you recount it here?
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Yeah, it was November 11th. I was 14, and I was visiting, and being a teenager with attitude I sat while the services started and the minute of silence. My grandfather grabbed me by the back of the shirt, by the back of the collar, lifted me up and he said, "You'll stand here and you'll respect our dad." Afterwards, after the time had passed on the television, I remember we were watching it on the television, I went to sit back down, and he made me stand for a full minute. After -- when we were done I was ordered to go to the kitchen table. I sat with him while he explained to me what it was like to be in Nazi Germany. He told me about the snitch lines, that if you wanted your neighbour's piano and they weren't going to give it to you, you just called up the Nazi snitch lines and they would take care of the family and you would go and get their belongings. They -- he talked to me about children who would go to school and the teachers would ask "What did your parents talk about last night?", and they would come home and find their families murdered because they said bad things about Hitler. The warning signs were here. We had people snitching on people at Christmastime enjoying family members, because there might have been sick people in a home that that person doesn't own. And then we watched Quebec police officers pull people out of those homes, throw them to the ground and arrest them because they were spending time with their family. We were headed down the road that my grandfather talked to -- talked to me about. I don't want to live that way. I want to live the way we have been in Canada. I want us to be united again. I want us to look at people and smile as we walk down the street. That works everywhere but the GTA. I mean, I want us to get back to where we were in 2019, that's all I want. It's not that much to ask for. We're not that far away. And we need to stop yelling at people and dividing and pitting each other against each other. We have a Prime Minister that was a former drama teacher and all he has done is -- has made Canada full of drama. He's very good at what he does.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay. So that was the last question. Thank you.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Do you believe that the Canadian Bill of Rights will help maintain our freedom providing ---
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: I'm not sure that's relevant to what we're doing here, but I'll let it go, but, please, we've heard your message, I think.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Yes, I understand.
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Providing it's allowed to be addressed in court, so I do believe that it's still valid and still exists.
speaker: MS. BRIGITTE BELTON

text_clean_combined: Okay?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: That's it.
speaker: MS. JANE SCHARF

text_clean_combined: Thank you.

speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU
